posts.title: The Blog is Back!
posts.markdown:
My blog is back! 
Well, the content is, at least. I'm planning on adding the medium content editor and doing a little roll-your-own CMS type exercise over the next few days. We'll see how that goes. Fingers crossed.

posts.title: Pay attention to your perception.
posts.markdown: One of the core values meditation has taught me is that when life experience is boiled down to pure essence, all that matters is what is in our own perception. Not to be so vain as to suggest that others should care what our perception contains, only that we should place intense concern on what our own perceptions contain.
posts.html: One of the core values meditation has taught me is that when life experience is boiled down to pure essence, all that matters is what is in our own perception. Not to be so vain as to suggest that others should care what our perception contains, only that we should place intense concern on what our own perceptions contain.

posts.title: Stuttering JavaScript animation
posts.markdown: I've been working out some methods to fix stuttering (janky) JS animation. One of the most common causes is DOM manipulation during animation. It just so happens that most tracking implementations out there work by adding small 1x1 pixel images to the page every time an event is tracked. So what do we do when our beautiful JavaScript animations are wrecked by tracking? Enter ActionDeferr.js. All that this simple script does is add functions to a queue, and then execute those functions when there is no animation taking place. At the time of this writing, I've only made it support jQuery and Greensock animation. Check it Out: https://github.com/keeganbrown/ActionDeferr
posts.html:
I've been working out some methods to fix stuttering (janky) JS animation. One of the most common causes is DOM manipulation during animation. It just so happens that most tracking implementations out there work by adding small 1x1 pixel images to the page every time an event is tracked. So what do we do when our beautiful JavaScript animations are wrecked by tracking? Enter ActionDeferr.js.

All that this simple script does is add functions to a queue, and then execute those functions when there is no animation taking place. At the time of this writing, I've only made it support jQuery and Greensock animation.

Check it Out:

https://github.com/keeganbrown/ActionDeferr

posts.title: The map and the terrain
posts.markdown:
The concept of the map versus the terrain is a common analogy in science and the philosophy of science. We're told not to confuse the map with the terrain -- not to confuse our understanding of a situation with the actual real situation. There's lots of reasons why we shouldn't assume that what we understand about our reality is in fact our reality, but a big one is that we shouldn't assume our understanding of reality is complete or correct. This analogy of map and terrain has a whole new meaning when applied to the mind. 
<!--more-->

The problem with self reflection on the nature of the mind is that the mind itself can contain delusions, persuasions, tricks, and assumptions. The very thing that we study in self reflection can trick us, and distract us, and throw us off course. Our very understanding of the mind can undo itself. It's as though the terrain has the ability to change the map.

This is why we've got to practice self reflection diligently, and why we can't just assume that we understand what we did and why we did it, without earnestly looking for those reasons. Luckily, our understanding of our own minds can increase readily if we put specific intentional focus on it.
posts.html:
The concept of the map versus the terrain is a common analogy in science and the philosophy of science. We're told not to confuse the map with the terrain -- not to confuse our understanding of a situation with the actual real situation. There's lots of reasons why we shouldn't assume that what we understand about our reality is in fact our reality, but a big one is that we shouldn't assume our understanding of reality is complete or correct. This analogy of map and terrain has a whole new meaning when applied to the mind.

The problem with self reflection on the nature of the mind is that the mind itself can contain delusions, persuasions, tricks, and assumptions. The very thing that we study in self reflection can trick us, and distract us, and throw us off course. Our very understanding of the mind can undo itself. posts.title: How to use a Zen Koan
posts.markdown: Zen koans boil down to unsolvable riddles. The task of zen practice is to ask your mind to solve them. So, to use a zen koan, you simply sit quietly and seek an answer to your selected koan. Your mind will at some point be forced to settle down and focus on your problem -- to which you'll find no answer. That is in fact the goal: to achieve stillness of mind in order by asking the mind to solve some it cannot.
posts.html: Zen koans boil down to unsolvable riddles. The task of zen practice is to ask your mind to solve them. So, to use a zen koan, you simply sit quietly and seek an answer to your selected koan. Your mind will at some point be forced to settle down and focus on your problem -- to which you'll find no answer. posts.title: Use jQuery AJAX to check if a file exists, without requesting the file
posts.html:
Neat solution, thought I'd save it. The important part is type: "head", which only returns the headers received from the request.

$.ajax({ type: 'HEAD', url: '/path/to/a/file.pdf', complete: function (e,d) { if ( e.status == 404 ) { alert("file does not exist") } } });

posts.title: How meditation works
posts.markdown:
A brief description of "how" meditation works, in my own words.

Meditation takes advantage of the phenomenon known as neuroplasticity, strengthening and training the brain to form new highly beneficial neuronal connections. The reason that the circuits formed in meditation are so beneficial, is because the skills practiced, strengthened, and honed during meditation are fundamental facets of "wise intelligence". Among these skills are: restraint, self reflection, concentration, focus, recall, contemplation, kindness, calmness, and self-soothing. 
<!--more-->
In essence, imagine that meditation is doing roughly the same thing as any other mental skill refinement -- improving the chosen skill, to the point of being a natural behavior. The core benefit is that the skills practiced are an echelon more useful in daily life than  many other mental skills we commonly practice.
posts.html:

posts.title: Every time to take an action, you practice a habit.
posts.markdown: Mull this over: every time you think or act in a certain way, you're contributing to the strength of the pathways that your brain creates to facilitate that action or thought. Think of it as constant practice for your brain -- your brain just keeps getting better at what you're doing. Except instead of an explicit action you're trying to get better at, you're just always getting better at whatever it is that you're doing, even if that thing isn't productive or good for you.
posts.html: Mull this over: every time you think or act in a certain way, you're contributing to the strength of the pathways that your brain creates to facilitate that action or thought. Think of it as constant practice for your brain -- your brain just keeps getting better at what you're doing. posts.title: Why global variables have slow performance in JavaScript.
posts.markdown:
I always really appreciate knowing why I should do something that people recommend to me. Maybe it's a bit of stubbornness, or maybe it's got something to do with distrusting information that comes to me without explanation. Either way, I don't like to take things on faith. A particularly good example of this behavior of mine backfiring occurred today, when I found out the "why" to a piece of advice I'd been given some time ago. I had stubbornly refused to follow some advice that had been given to me about using Local Function Variables, rather than Global Variables. I didn't completely not follow the advice, but I did find myself not really caring whether or not I followed it.
Global variables have slow performance because they live in a highly-populated namespace. Not only are they stored along with many other user-defined quantities and JavaScript variables, the browser must also distinguish between global variables and properties of objects that are in the current context. Thanks Joseph Myers!
Boom. A simple, totally sensical, explanation. I wish I would have had this explanation years ago. Side Note: This doesn't excuse declaring and re-declaring variables inside loops.
posts.html:
I always really appreciate knowing why I should do something that people recommend to me. Maybe it's a bit of stubbornness, or maybe it's got something to do with distrusting information that comes to me without explanation. Either way, I don't like to take things on faith. A particularly good example of this behavior of mine backfiring occurred today, when I found out the "why" to a piece of advice I'd been given some time ago.

I had stubbornly refused to follow some advice that had been given to me about using Local Function Variables, rather than Global Variables. I didn't completely not follow the advice, but I did find myself not really caring whether or not I followed it.
Global variables have slow performance because they live in a highly-populated namespace. Not only are they stored along with many other user-defined quantities and JavaScript variables, the browser must also distinguish between global variables and properties of objects that are in the current context. Thanks Joseph Myers!

Boom. A simple, totally sensical, explanation. I wish I would have had this explanation years ago.

Side Note: This doesn't excuse declaring and re-declaring variables inside loops.

posts.title: The concept of no-self
posts.markdown:
Three keys to the concept of "egolessness" or "no-self", and my brief interpretations.

1. No sensations can observe other sensations -- therefore you are not a sensation.
1. No sensations have special control of other sensations -- therefore, there is no reason to be particularly afraid of one sensation over another.
1. No sensations occur separately from other sensations in each moment -- all sensations occur fundamentally within the same realm and time.
posts.html:
Three keys to the concept of "egolessness" or "no-self", and my brief interpretations.

  1. No sensations can observe other sensations -- therefore you are not a sensation.
  2. No sensations have special control of other sensations -- therefore, there is no reason to be particularly afraid of one sensation over another.
  3. No sensations occur separately from other sensations in each moment -- all sensations occur fundamentally within the same realm and time.

posts.title: What is Ego?
posts.markdown:
I figured I'd give my stab at trying to define ego, as it relates to meditation practice. 

"Ego" is type of a momentary, fleeting sensation that tricks the mind into thinking "I am this, but not that. I am this way, not that way."
<!--more-->

That's not to say that there is no true self, nor that your self does not have particular attributes -- rather its a caution that if you have a sensation telling you what you are or aren't, that sensation is most certainly misrepresenting your true self.

You do not need sensations to tell you who or what you are ;)
posts.html:

posts.title: Two words on "Focus"
posts.markdown: Two words on focus: * Focus frequently. * Focus freely. * Focus completely. * Focus your thoughts. * Focus your feelings. * Focus your self control. * Focus expertly. * Focus with all of yourself. * Focus intentionally. * Focus correctly. * Focus until it hurts. * Keep focusing until it doesn't hurt anymore.
posts.html:
Two words on focus:

  • Focus frequently.
  • Focus freely.
  • Focus completely.
  • Focus your thoughts.
  • Focus your feelings.
  • Focus your self control.
  • Focus expertly.
  • Focus with all of yourself.
  • Focus intentionally.
  • Focus correctly.
  • Focus until it hurts.
  • Keep focusing until it doesn't hurt anymore.

posts.title: Five foundations
posts.markdown:
I've never agreed completely with any particular set of spiritual teachings. That's actually one of the reasons I'm drawn to Buddhism -- it asks you to to investigate for yourself; it requires you not to take someone else's word for it. I don't actually consider myself buddhist -- I'm not fond of labels or boxes like that ( or cliches ;-P ). Instead, I find that many buddhist teachings resonate well with me -- there's certainly buddhist teachings I don't agree with. Describing exactly how I feel about this isn't easy for me. I often find myself disagreeing with spiritual people and straight up materialists alike. Perusing the hallowed halls of reddit.com/r/meditation I found a nice free ebook that put how I feel into words. These came in the form of "five foundations" Here are the five foundations:
  1. Clarify Your Aspiration
  2. Unconditional Follow-Through
  3. Never Abdicate Your Authority
  4. Practice Absolute Sincerity
  5. Be a Good Steward of Your Life

Get the Ebook

posts.title: A quick and easy trick to fix clunky Javascript animations on mobile
posts.html:
Animating mobile web content javascript can easily produce clunky looking animation unless you follow these guideines.

  1. Don't Manipulate the DOM while you're animating stuff.
    This will make animation clunky even on desktop browsers. DOM manipulation includes adding or removing elements from the DOM -or- changing attributes of DOM elements (including class names or other attributes). DOM manipulation can even occurr in ways you wouldn't expect -- say if you've got custom analytics event scripting. If you absolutely have to do this kind of evented analytics (it's hard to get away from on a corporate development level) then you can at least defer your tracking events. This script I wrote might help.
  2. Prevent scrolling.
    Scrolling the page on most mobile devices (including some tablets) will often prevent all animation from occurring until the scroll stops.
  3. Leverage a little CSS3. CSS3 animations and transitions can go a long way to making Javascript animations perform like butter on mobile devices. Even if you're still animating with plain 'ol jQuery, the following CSS3 can still help.
    #box-around-animated-content { -webkit-transform: translate3d(0,0,0); -moz-transform: translate3d(0,0,0); -ms-transform: translate3d(0,0,0); transform: translate3d(0,0,0); }
    Note that you might need to be a little reserved in how you apply this trick. Doing so engages hardware acceleration on the device, which can have some pretty weird side effects on your page. Use it sparingly -- using this trick on too many boxes on the page will cause the device to stop hardware acceleration altogether, and your animations will go back to being clunky. This trick works great on iOS devices and newer android devices. Be sure to check your page in older android devices if you use this trick.

posts.title: My favorite Inspiring Steve Jobs Quote
posts.markdown:
From Steve Jobs' 2005 Stanford Commencement Address:
Remembering that you are going to die is the best way I know to avoid the trap of thinking you have something to lose. You are already naked. There is no reason not to follow your heart.
posts.html:
From Steve Jobs' 2005 Stanford Commencement Address:

Remembering that you are going to die is the best way I know to avoid the trap of thinking you have something to lose. You are already naked. There is no reason not to follow your heart.

posts.title: Ulysses' Ship
posts.markdown: Plato's riddle of Ulysses' ship is a long standing philosophy riddle that I've recently come to realize has subtle significance to the real world. The riddle, which has been rehashed as rephrased countless times since it's inception, goes something like this: Ulysses returns home from a voyage ad docks his ship on one side of the river. After disembarking he instructs his crew to dismantle his boat piece by piece, and reassemble the ship at the dock on the other side of the river. The question then, is: at what point is Ulysses' Ship no longer docked on one side of the river, and at what point is it docked in the other side? Ask this riddle to numerous people, and you're bound to get numerous answers. The answer I've found most satisfying is as follows: There is no such thing as Ulysses Ship -- the ship itself is an abstract concept that only exists in the mind of those who consider it. The only reason that Ulysses may claim to own a ship is that there's a relative agreement between the beliefs of people have an idea of what a ship is and how someone might claim to have one. This is the reason that there's no consistent answer to this riddle -- it depends on ones personal beliefs. More so -- it illustrates a deeper truth of our human lives. We, as human beings, primarily act upon and with concepts as though they are real things. This is certainly out of optimization of thought and language -- it's easier to say ship than to list the qualities you might find acceptable as a ship. I can't help thinking that these optimizations a have blurred our insight into the deeper, more real description of reality. Perhaps if we take the time to fully understand what these optimizations are hiding, we'll uncover some far more useful facets of reality.
posts.html:
Plato's riddle of Ulysses' ship is a long standing philosophy riddle that I've recently come to realize has subtle significance to the real world. The riddle, which has been rehashed as rephrased countless times since it's inception, goes something like this:

Ulysses returns home from a voyage ad docks his ship on one side of the river. After disembarking he instructs his crew to dismantle his boat piece by piece, and reassemble the ship at the dock on the other side of the river. The question then, is: at what point is Ulysses' Ship no longer docked on one side of the river, and at what point is it docked in the other side?

Ask this riddle to numerous people, and you're bound to get numerous answers. The answer I've found most satisfying is as follows:

There is no such thing as Ulysses Ship -- the ship itself is an abstract concept that only exists in the mind of those who consider it. The only reason that Ulysses may claim to own a ship is that there's a relative agreement between the beliefs of people have an idea of what a ship is and how someone might claim to have one. This is the reason that there's no consistent answer to this riddle -- it depends on ones personal beliefs.

More so -- it illustrates a deeper truth of our human lives. We, as human beings, primarily act upon and with concepts as though they are real things. This is certainly out of optimization of thought and language -- it's easier to say ship than to list the qualities you might find acceptable as a ship. I can't help thinking that these optimizations a have blurred our insight into the deeper, more real description of reality. Perhaps if we take the time to fully understand what these optimizations are hiding, we'll uncover some far more useful facets of reality.

posts.markdown: An ally is almost always more valuable than an enemy.

posts.title: 99% Belief
posts.markdown: Believe with up to 99% of yourself -- for that 1% you leave of doubt is your lifeline to clear and rational thought.
